sen.j: 斯波 高経（しば たかつね、嘉元3年（1305年） - 貞治6年/正平 (日本)22年7月13日 (旧暦)（1367年8月9日））は、南北朝時代 (日本)の武将、守護大名。
sen.e: Takatsune SHIBA (1305 - August 17, 1367) was a Japanese military commander and provincial military governor in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
sen.cmt: 貞治6年/正平 (日本)22年7月13日 (旧暦)（1367年8月9日）： 原文の西暦はユリウス暦で記されています。英文ではグレゴリオ暦で訳しました。
sen.e: Takatsune SHIBA (1305 - August 17, 1367) was a Japanese military commander and provincial military governor in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
Takatsune SHIBA (1305 - August 17, 1367) was a busho (Japanese military commander) and provincial military governor in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
sen.cmt: 武将は初回ですのでbushoを入れました。

sen.j: 本姓は源氏。
sen.e: His real family name was Genji.
His real family name was Genji.
His real family name was Genji.

sen.j: 家系は清和源氏の一家系 河内源氏の棟梁 鎮守府将軍源義家の子 源義国を祖とする足利氏の一門 斯波氏。
sen.e: His family lineage was the Shiba clan, which was a family of the Ashikaga clan that originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshikuni, who was a son of MINAMOTO no Yoshiie who was the head of the Kawachi-Genji, which was one of the families of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa), and a Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North.

His family lineage was the Shiba clan, which was a family of the Ashikaga clan that originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshikuni, who was a son of MINAMOTO no Yoshiie who was the head of the Kawachi-Genji, which was one of the families of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa), and a Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North.

His family lineage was the Shiba clan, which was a family of the Ashikaga clan that originated from MINAMOTO no Yoshikuni, a son of MINAMOTO no Yoshiie who was the head of the Kawachi-Genji-- one of the families of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa)--and Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).
sen.cmt: 鎮守府将軍は初回ですのでChinju-fu shogun を入れました。また、関係詞が続くので一部変更しました。

sen.j: 幼名を千鶴丸、通称を孫三郎と称す。
sen.e: His childhood name was Sentsurumaru and he was commonly called Saburo.
His childhood name was Sentsurumaru and he was commonly called Saburo.
His childhood name was Sentsurumaru and he was commonly called Saburo.

sen.j: 父は斯波宗氏（家貞）、母は大江時秀の娘。
sen.e: His father was Muneuji (Iesada) SHIBA and mother was a daughter of Tokihide OE.
His father was Muneuji (Iesada) SHIBA and mother was a daughter of Tokihide OE.
His father was Muneuji (Iesada) SHIBA and mother was a daughter of Tokihide OE.

sen.j: 家系
sen.e: Family line
Family line
Family line

sen.j: 源氏の一流、河内源氏の名門、足利氏の一門。
sen.e: His family was part of the Ashikaga clan, one of the main families of the Kawachi-Genji, the Minamoto clan.
His family was part of the Ashikaga clan, one of the main families of the Kawachi-Genji, the Minamoto clan.
His family was part of the Ashikaga clan, one of the main families of the Kawachi-Genji, the Minamoto clan.

sen.j: 尾張流足利家の嫡流にあたる。
sen.e: His family was the main branch of the Owari-Ashikaga family.
His family was the main branch of the Owari-Ashikaga family.
His family was the main branch of the Owari-Ashikaga family.

sen.j: 名門ゆえに足利姓の公称を許されており、斯波氏を称するのは高祖父の家氏とも、高経ともいう。
sen.e: His family were allowed to identify themselves as Ashikaga in public because they were a family of good pedigree, and it was apparently his great-great-grandfather Ieuji or Takatsune himself that described themselves as the Shiba family.

His family were allowed to identify themselves as Ashikaga in public because they were a family of good pedigree, and it was apparently his great-great-grandfather Ieuji or Takatsune himself that described themselves as the Shiba family.

His family were allowed to identify themselves as Ashikaga in public because they were a family of good pedigree, and it was apparently his great-great-grandfather Ieuji or Takatsune himself that described themselves as the Shiba family.

sen.j: 室町幕府が成立すると斯波義将が管領となり、父の高経がその後見をつとめた。
sen.e: When the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) came into power, Yoshimasa SHIBA became kanrei (shogunal deputy) and his father Takatsune acted as the guardian.
When the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) came into power, Yoshimasa SHIBA became kanrei (shogunal deputy) and his father Takatsune acted as the guardian.
When the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) came into power, Yoshimasa SHIBA became kanrei (shogunal deputy) and his father Takatsune acted as the guardian.
sen.cmt: スペースをとりました。

sen.j: 以後、室町時代を通して斯波氏は三管領の筆頭となった。
sen.e: After that, the Shiba clan became the head of sankanrei (three families in the post of kanrei, or shogunal deputy) throughout the Muromachi period.
After that, the Shiba clan became the head of sankanrei (three families in the post of kanrei, or shogunal deputy) throughout the Muromachi period.
After that, the Shiba clan became the head of sankanrei (three families in the post of kanrei, or shogunal deputy) throughout the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 詳細は斯波氏を参照。
sen.e: For details see 'Shiba clan'.
For details see 'Shiba clan'.
For details see 'Shiba clan.'
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 高経の子には、斯波義将の他に斯波家長、斯波氏経、斯波氏頼、斯波義種がおり、弟には奥州斯波氏の祖となる斯波家兼らがいる。
sen.e: His children included Ienaga SHIBA, Ujitsune SHIBA, Ujiyori SHIBA and Yoshitane SHIBA in addition to Yoshimasa SHIBA, and his brothers included Iekane SHIBA who became the originator of the Oshu-Shiba clan.

His children included Ienaga SHIBA, Ujitsune SHIBA, Ujiyori SHIBA and Yoshitane SHIBA in addition to Yoshimasa SHIBA, and his brothers included Iekane SHIBA who became the originator of the Oshu-Shiba clan.

His children included Ienaga SHIBA, Ujitsune SHIBA, Ujiyori SHIBA and Yoshitane SHIBA in addition to Yoshimasa SHIBA, and his brothers included Iekane SHIBA who became the originator of the Oshu-Shiba clan.

The family tree

sen.j: 源義家－源義国－足利義康－足利義兼－足利義氏 (足利家3代目当主)－足利泰氏－斯波家氏－斯波宗家－斯波家貞－斯波高経－斯波義将
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshiie - MINAMOTO no Yoshikuni - Yoshiyasu ASHIKAGA - Yoshikane ASHIKAGA - Yoshiuji ASHIKAGA (the third head of ASHIKAGA family) -Yasuuji ASHIKAGA - Ieuji SHIBA - Muneie SHIBA - Iesada SHIBA - Takatsune SHIBA - Yoshimasa SHIBA.

MINAMOTO no Yoshiie - MINAMOTO no Yoshikuni - Yoshiyasu ASHIKAGA - Yoshikane ASHIKAGA - Yoshiuji ASHIKAGA (the third head of ASHIKAGA family) -Yasuuji ASHIKAGA - Ieuji SHIBA - Muneie SHIBA - Iesada SHIBA - Takatsune SHIBA - Yoshimasa SHIBA.

MINAMOTO no Yoshiie - MINAMOTO no Yoshikuni - Yoshiyasu ASHIKAGA - Yoshikane ASHIKAGA - Yoshiuji ASHIKAGA (the third head of ASHIKAGA family) -Yasuuji ASHIKAGA - Ieuji SHIBA - Muneie SHIBA - Iesada SHIBA - Takatsune SHIBA - Yoshimasa SHIBA.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

tit.e: The battle against the Nitta family
The battle against the Nitta family
The battle against the Nitta family

sen.j: 元弘3年（1333年）に後醍醐天皇の綸旨に応じた足利尊氏に従い、鎌倉攻めに参加する。
sen.e: In 1333, he joined in an attack on Kamakura (Kamakura-zeme) following Takauji ASHIKAGA who was acting in response to a statement by the Emperor Godaigo.
In 1333, he joined in an attack on Kamakura (Kamakura-zeme) following Takauji ASHIKAGA who was acting in response to a statement by the Emperor Godaigo.
In 1333, he joined in an attack on Kamakura (Kamakura-zeme) following Takauji ASHIKAGA who was acting in response to a statement by the Emperor Godaigo.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府滅亡後に後醍醐天皇による建武の新政が行われ、後に尊氏らが建武政権から離反するとこれにも従って、以後武家方の有力武将として各地を転戦する。
sen.e: Kenmu no Shinsei (the new government of Emperor Godaigo and the new policies) was started by Emperor Godaigo after the fall of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), but later, Takatsune followed Takauji when Takauji seceded from the Kenmu government, and Takatsune took part in various battles in various places as a powerful military commander of samurai warriors (the Ashikaga side) since then.

Kenmu no Shinsei (the new government of Emperor Godaigo and the new policies) was started by Emperor Godaigo after the fall of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), but later, Takatsune followed Takauji when Takauji seceded from the Kenmu government, and Takatsune took part in various battles in various places as a powerful military commander of samurai warriors (the Ashikaga side) since then.

Kenmu no Shinsei (the new government of Emperor Godaigo and the new policies) was started by Emperor Godaigo after the fall of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), but later, Takatsune followed Takauji when Takauji seceded from the Kenmu government, and Takatsune took part in various battles in various places as a powerful military commander of samurai warriors since then.
sen.cmt: (the Ashikaga side)は和文にはないため削除しました。スペースをとりました。

sen.j: 延元元年/建武 (日本)3年（1336年）の新田義貞、楠木正成との間で行われた湊川の戦いにも参陣。
sen.e: Takatsune joined the Battle of Minato-gawa River between Yoshisada NITTA and Masashige KUSUNOKI in 1336 too.
Takatsune joined the Battle of Minato-gawa River between Yoshisada NITTA and Masashige KUSUNOKI in 1336 too.
Takatsune joined the Battle of Minato-gawa River between Yoshisada NITTA and Masashige KUSUNOKI in 1336 too.

sen.j: 足利尊氏が京都に武家政権を成立させ、後醍醐らが吉野に南朝を成立させて南北朝時代となると、越前国守護として主に北陸方面で南朝方と攻防を繰り広げた。
sen.e: When it came to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, during which Takauji ASHIKAGA formed a samurai government in Kyoto (the Northern Court) and Emperor Godaigo set up the Southern Court in Yoshino, Takatsune became engaged in a tug-of-war against the Southern Court, mainly in Hokuriku region as a military governor of Echizen Province.
sen.cmt: 武家政権＝北朝だということを示して読者の理解を助けるため、英訳では (the Northern Court) を付記しました。
sen.e: When it came to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, during which Takauji ASHIKAGA formed a samurai government in Kyoto (the Northern Court) and Emperor Godaigo set up the Southern Court in Yoshino, Takatsune became engaged in a tug-of-war against the Southern Court, mainly in Hokuriku region as a military governor of Echizen Province.

When it came to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, during which Takauji ASHIKAGA formed a samurai government in Kyoto (the Northern Court) and Emperor Godaigo set up the Southern Court in Yoshino, Takatsune became engaged in a tug-of-war against the Southern Court, mainly in Hokuriku region as a military governor of Echizen Province.

sen.j: 湊川の戦い後、新田義貞が、尊良親王、恒良親王を奉じて越前へ入国し、越前での戦況は激しさを増していった。
sen.e: Because Yoshisada NITTA's army entered Echizen Province with Imperial Prince Takayoshi and Imperial Prince Tsuneyoshi at its head, after the Battle of Minato-gawa River, the war situation in Echizen grew intense.

Because Yoshisada NITTA's army entered Echizen Province with Imperial Prince Takayoshi and Imperial Prince Tsuneyoshi at its head, after the Battle of Minato-gawa River, the war situation in Echizen grew intense.

Because Yoshisada NITTA's army entered Echizen Province with Imperial Prince Takayoshi and Imperial Prince Tsuneyoshi at its head, after the Battle of Minato-gawa River, the war situation in Echizen grew intense.

sen.j: 延元2年/建武4年（1337年）に、越前で高師泰と共に南朝方の金ケ崎城（福井県敦賀市）を攻め、両親王を擁した義貞、新田義顕親子を破る。
sen.e: In 1337, Takatsune attacked Kanagasaki-jo Castle (Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture) of the Southern Court in Echizen with KO no Moroyasu and defeated Yoshisada and his son Yoshiaki NITTA who had both Imperial Princes on their side.

In 1337, Takatsune attacked Kanagasaki-jo Castle (Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture) of the Southern Court in Echizen with KO no Moroyasu and defeated Yoshisada and his son Yoshiaki NITTA who had both Imperial Princes on their side.

In 1337, Takatsune attacked Kanagasaki-jo Castle (Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture) of the Southern Court in Echizen with KO no Moroyasu and defeated Yoshisada and his son Yoshiaki NITTA who had both Imperial Princes on their side.

sen.j: 事実上の大将であった義貞こそ取り逃がしたものの、尊良親王と義顕を自害させ、恒良親王を捕らえるなどの軍功をあげる。
sen.e: Although letting Yoshisada, who was a de facto commander, get away, Takatsune's other military exploits included making Imperial Prince Takayoshi and Yoshiaki commit suicide and capturing Imperial Prince Tsuneyoshi.

Although letting Yoshisada, who was a de facto commander, get away, Takatsune's other military exploits included making Imperial Prince Takayoshi and Yoshiaki commit suicide and capturing Imperial Prince Tsuneyoshi.

Although letting Yoshisada, who was a de facto commander, get away, Takatsune's other military exploits included making Imperial Prince Takayoshi and Yoshiaki commit suicide and capturing Imperial Prince Tsuneyoshi.

sen.j: その後新田義貞の巻き返しによって府中や金ヶ崎城を奪われたが、高経は平泉寺の宗徒を自陣営に抱き込んで義貞の攻勢を防いだ。
sen.e: After that, Takatsune was deprived of his Fuchu (cities which have local governments at their core) and Kanagasaki-jo Castle as a result of a resumed offensive from Yoshisada NITTA, but he held off Yoshisada's offence by bringing temple-goers of Heisen-ji Temple over to his side.

After that, Takatsune was deprived of his Fuchu (cities which have local governments at their core) and Kanagasaki-jo Castle as a result of a resumed offensive from Yoshisada NITTA, but he held off Yoshisada's offence by bringing temple-goers of Heisen-ji Temple over to his side.

After that, Takatsune was deprived of his Fuchu (cities which have local governments at their core) and Kanagasaki-jo Castle as a result of a resumed offensive from Yoshisada NITTA, but he held off Yoshisada's offence by bringing temple-goers of Heisen-ji Temple over to his side.

sen.j: そして延元3年/建武5年（1338年）閏7月、越前藤島の灯明寺畷においてついに義貞自身を討ち取る大功をあげた。
sen.e: In August 1338, Takatsune finally scored a big success, killing Yoshisada on a footpath between rice fields of Tomyo-ji Temple in Fujishima, Echizen Province.
In August 1338, Takatsune finally scored a big success, killing Yoshisada on a footpath between rice fields of Tomyo-ji Temple in Fujishima, Echizen Province.
In August 1338, Takatsune finally scored a big success, killing Yoshisada at Tomyoji Nawate (a footpath between rice fields of Tomyo-ji Temple) in Fujishima, Echizen Province.
sen.cmt: 灯明寺畷は地名（名所）となっているため、そのまま用いました。http://www.fukuicity-navi.com/090_others/walk_english/pdf/pdf_map1.pdf

sen.j: 暦応2年/延元4年（1339年）からは義貞の弟脇屋義助が宮方の大将として立ち塞がり、一時は越前から加賀へ落ちるなど苦戦を味わった。
sen.e: Takatsune had Yoshisada's younger brother Yoshisuke WAKIYA as the court's side commander before him from 1339 and faced an uphill battle, meaning he had to run away from Echizen to Kaga Province for a time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Takatsune had Yoshisada's younger brother Yoshisuke WAKIYA as the court's side commander before him from 1339 and faced an uphill battle, meaning he had to run away from Echizen to Kaga Province for a time.

Takatsune had Yoshisada's younger brother Yoshisuke WAKIYA as the court's side commander before him from 1339 and faced an uphill battle, meaning he had to run away from Echizen to Kaga Province for a time.

sen.j: しかし、暦応3年/興国元年（1340年）に反攻をしかけ義助を美濃へ追い、暦応4年/興国2年（1341年）残る宮方勢力を討ち破り越前を平定した。
sen.e: However, Takatsune made a countercharge to expel Yoshisuke from Mino Province in 1340 and breaking through the rest of the court's forces to subjugate Echizen in 1341.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, Takatsune made a countercharge to expel Yoshisuke from Mino Province in 1340 and breaking through the rest of the court's forces to subjugate Echizen in 1341.
However, Takatsune made a countercharge to expel Yoshisuke to Mino Province in 1340 and breaking through the rest of the court's forces to subjugate Echizen in 1341.
sen.cmt: 越前から美濃へ追いと解釈し、前置詞を変更しました。

sen.j: やがて足利家の内紛から発展した観応の擾乱が起こると、はじめ足利直義方に与してその有力武将となるも、後に足利尊氏方についた。
sen.e: Before long, when the Kanno Disturbance, which had grown from the internal conflict in the Ashikaga family, happened, Takatsune took sides with Naoyoshi ASHIKAGA at first and became a powerful military commander, but later he took the side of Takauji ASHIKAGA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Before long, when the Kanno Disturbance, which had grown from the internal conflict in the Ashikaga family, happened, Takatsune took sides with Naoyoshi ASHIKAGA at first and became a powerful military commander, but later he took the side of Takauji ASHIKAGA.

Before long, when the Kanno Disturbance, which had grown from the internal conflict in the Ashikaga family, happened, Takatsune took sides with Naoyoshi ASHIKAGA at first and became a powerful military commander, but later he took the side of Takauji ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 正平一統における南朝方の京都制圧においては、足利義詮を助けて京都奪還に功をあげた。
sen.e: When the South Court tried to take control of Kyoto - Shohei itto (temporal unification of the Northern and Southern Courts) - Takatsune assisted Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA in recapturing Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When the South Court tried to take control of Kyoto - Shohei itto (temporal unification of the Northern and Southern Courts) - Takatsune assisted Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA in recapturing Kyoto.
When the South Court tried to take control of Kyoto - Shohei itto (temporal unification of the Northern and Southern Courts) - Takatsune assisted Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA in recapturing Kyoto.

sen.j: しかし正平10年/文和4年（1355年）、足利直冬に呼応して再び幕府に反旗を翻し、今度は自身が京都を制圧するに至った。
sen.e: In 1355, however, Takatsune led a rebellion against the bakufu again in response to Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA and came to control Kyoto by himself this time.
In 1355, however, Takatsune led a rebellion against the bakufu again in response to Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA and came to control Kyoto by himself this time.
In 1355, however, Takatsune led a rebellion against the bakufu again in response to Tadafuyu ASHIKAGA and came to control Kyoto by himself this time.

sen.j: 正平12年/延文元年（1356年）、直冬方から離反しまたも幕府へ帰参する。
sen.e: In 1356, he left Tadafuyu's side and returned to the bakufu again.
In 1356, he left Tadafuyu's side and returned to the bakufu again.
In 1356, he left Tadafuyu's side and returned to the bakufu again.

sen.j: 正平13年/延文3年（1358年）、尊氏が死去すると剃髪し道朝と称して2代将軍となった義詮の補佐を行う。
sen.e: When Takauji died in 1358, he took the tonsure, renamed himself Docho and assisted Yoshiakira who became the second Shogun.
When Takauji died in 1358, he took the tonsure, renamed himself Docho and assisted Yoshiakira who became the second Shogun.
When Takauji died in 1358, he took the tonsure, renamed himself Docho and assisted Yoshiakira who became the second Shogun.

sen.j: 康安元年/正平16年（1361年）に、それまで執事（後の管領）であった細川清氏が失脚して南朝へ下ると斯波家の力が強まり、高経は康安2年/正平17年（1362年）に子の斯波義将を執事（管領）職に就かせ、実権は自身が握って幕政を主導した。
sen.e: The fact that Kiyouji HOSOKAWA fell from the position of shitsuji (the later kanrei [shognal deputy]) and ran away to the Southern Court let the Shiba family get more power, and Takatsune placed his son Yoshimasa SHIBA in the post of shitsuji in 1362 and he himself got the real power to take the initiative in bakufu.

The fact that Kiyouji HOSOKAWA fell from the position of shitsuji (the later kanrei [shognal deputy]) and ran away to the Southern Court let the Shiba family get more power, and Takatsune placed his son Yoshimasa SHIBA in the post of shitsuji in 1362 and he himself got the real power to take the initiative in bakufu.

The fact that Kiyouji HOSOKAWA fell from the position of shitsuji (the later kanrei [shognal deputy]) and ran away to the Southern Court let the Shiba family get more power, and Takatsune placed his son Yoshimasa SHIBA in the post of shitsuji in 1362 and he himself got the real power to take the initiative in bakufu.

sen.j: また5男の斯波義種を小侍所の頭人に据えるなど幕府中枢を斯波一族で占めた。
sen.e: Also he placed his fifth son Yoshitane SHIBA as the head of a group of officers to guard the Shogun, and the Shiba family took a hold on the nucleus of the Bakufu.
Also he placed his fifth son Yoshitane SHIBA as the head of a group of officers to guard the Shogun, and the Shiba family took a hold on the nucleus of the Bakufu.
Also he placed his fifth son Yoshitane SHIBA as the head of kozamurai dokoro (a group of officers to guard the Shogun), and the Shiba family took a hold on the nucleus of the Bakufu.
sen.cmt: kozamurai dokoro 挿入しました。

sen.j: 幕府の実権を握った高経であったが、その強権的な政治は諸大名や寺社勢力からの反発を招くに至る。
sen.e: Takatsune got the real power of the bakufu, but his uncompromising political style triggered protests by territorial lords and temple and shrine groups.
Takatsune got the real power of the bakufu, but his uncompromising political style triggered protests by territorial lords and temple and shrine groups.
Takatsune got the real power of the bakufu, but his uncompromising political style triggered protests by territorial lords and temple and shrine groups.

sen.j: 特に高経の3男斯波氏頼の舅であった佐々木道誉（京極高氏）は、かつて自身の推す氏頼を退けて義将を管領とした高経を憎んでいたため、両者は激しく対立する。
sen.e: Especially, Doyo SASAKI (Takauji KYOGOKU), who was the father-in-law of Ujiyori SHIBA who was the third son of Takatsune, hated Takatsune because Takatsune had made Yoshimasa kanrei rejecting Ujiyori whom Doyo had pushed, and both were in fierce conflict.

Especially, Doyo SASAKI (Takauji KYOGOKU), who was the father-in-law of Ujiyori SHIBA who was the third son of Takatsune, hated Takatsune because Takatsune had made Yoshimasa kanrei rejecting Ujiyori whom Doyo had pushed, and both were in fierce conflict.

Especially, Doyo SASAKI (Takauji KYOGOKU), who was the father-in-law of Ujiyori SHIBA who was the third son of Takatsune, hated Takatsune because Takatsune had made Yoshimasa kanrei rejecting Ujiyori whom Doyo had pushed, and both were in fierce conflict.

sen.j: 正平21年/貞治5年（1366年）8月、突如として将軍義詮より領国へ戻るように命じられ失脚した（貞治の変）。
sen.e: In August 1366, suddenly he was ordered to go back to his territory by Shogun Yoshiakira and was toppled (the Joji incident).
In August 1366, suddenly he was ordered to go back to his territory by Shogun Yoshiakira and was toppled (the Joji incident).
In August 1366, suddenly he was ordered to go back to his territory by Shogun Yoshiakira and was toppled (the Joji incident).

sen.j: 後任の管領には道誉が推す細川頼之が就任したため義将の幕政復帰後も斯波氏と細川氏の対立構図は残り、3代将軍足利義満時代の康暦の政変へとつながっていく。
sen.e: Because Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, for whom Doyo pushed, assumed the post of substitute kanrei, the conflict between the Shiba family and the Hosokawa family remained after Yoshimasa had come back to the shogunate government; this conflict led to the Koryaku Coup in the time of the third Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.

Because Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, for whom Doyo pushed, assumed the post of substitute kanrei, the conflict between the Shiba family and the Hosokawa family remained after Yoshimasa had come back to the shogunate government; this conflict led to the Koryaku Coup in the time of the third Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.

Because Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, for whom Doyo pushed, assumed the post of substitute kanrei, the conflict between the Shiba family and the Hosokawa family remained after Yoshimasa had come back to the shogunate government; this conflict led to the Koryaku Coup in the time of the third Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 都落ちした高経は幕府の討伐軍に屈す事無く戦い続けたが、貞治6年/正平22年（1367年）に杣山城（福井県南越前町）で死去。
sen.e: Although Takatsune, who had fled the capital, continued to fight against a punitive force from the government, he died at Somayama-jo Castle (Minamiechizen-cho, Fukui Prefecture) in 1367.
Although Takatsune, who had fled the capital, continued to fight against a punitive force from the government, he died at Somayama-jo Castle (Minamiechizen-cho, Fukui Prefecture) in 1367.
Although Takatsune, who had fled the capital, continued to fight against a punitive force from the government, he died at Somayama-jo Castle (Minamiechizen-cho, Fukui Prefecture) in 1367.

sen.j: 享年63。
sen.e: He was sixty-three years old.
He was sixty-three years old.
He was sixty-three years old.

sen.j: 法名は東光寺（のち霊源院）殿道朝日峯。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name was Tokoji (Reigenin later) den Docho-nippo.
sen.cmt: 「東光寺（のち霊源院）殿道朝日峯」の読みは確認できませんでした。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name was Tokoji (Reigenin later) den Docho-nippo.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Tokoji (Reigenin later) den Docho-nippo.

sen.j: なお高経の死後、義将はまもなく赦免され幕府に復帰している。
sen.e: In addition, after Takatsune's death, Yoshimasa was pardoned after a short time and came back to bakufu.
In addition, after Takatsune's death, Yoshimasa was pardoned after a short time and came back to bakufu.
In addition, after Takatsune's death, Yoshimasa was pardoned after a short time and came back to bakufu.

sen.j: 『太平記』において新田義貞を藤島にて討ち取った際、鬼切と鬼丸の二振りの名刀を手に入れたとされる。
sen.e: It is said in "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace) that Takatsune obtained notable swords called Onikiri and Onimaru when he killed Yoshisada NITTA in Fujishima.
sen.cmt: ＷＥＢで「鬼切と鬼丸」となっている箇所が、原文では「髭切と鬼丸」になっていたので、ＷＥＢに沿って原文も「髭切」を「鬼切」と改め、英訳でも Onikiri としました。
sen.e: It is said in "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace) that Takatsune obtained notable swords called Onikiri and Onimaru when he killed Yoshisada NITTA in Fujishima.
It is said in "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace) that Takatsune obtained notable swords called Onikiri and Onimaru when he killed Yoshisada NITTA in Fujishima.

sen.j: 後日、足利尊氏が「それは源氏重代の家宝だから」と引渡しを求めたが、高経は「焼けてしまった」と言って焼けた太刀を渡した。
sen.e: The next day, Takauji ASHIKAGA demanded the handover of the two swords, saying 'they are hereditary family heirlooms of the Minamoto clan,' but Takatsune said 'they burned' and handed Takauji two burned-out swords.

The next day, Takauji ASHIKAGA demanded the handover of the two swords, saying 'they are hereditary family heirlooms of the Minamoto clan,' but Takatsune said 'they burned' and handed Takauji two burned-out swords.

The next day, Takauji ASHIKAGA demanded the handover of the two swords, saying 'they are hereditary family heirlooms of the Minamoto clan,' but Takatsune said 'they burned' and handed Takauji two burned-out swords.

sen.j: 尊氏は真相を知ると非常に機嫌を損ねたという。
sen.e: Takauji was offended badly when he found out the truth.
Takauji was offended badly when he found out the truth.
Takauji was offended badly when he found out the truth.

sen.j: 後年、高経が失脚すると鬼丸は室町将軍家の手に渡り、鬼切は斯波一族の最上氏に伝来した。
sen.e: In later years, once Takatsune downfell, Onimaru was obtained once more by the Muromachi shogunate family and Onikiri was given to the Mogami family of the Shiba family.
In later years, after the downfall of Takatsune, Onimaru was obtained once more by the Muromachi shogunate family and Onikiri was given to the Mogami family of the Shiba family.
In later years, after the downfall of Takatsune, Onimaru was obtained once more by the Muromachi shogunate family and Onikiri was given to and handed down in the Mogami family of the Shiba family.
sen.cmt: 伝来の意味を追加しました。

sen.j: 高経が政権を掌握していた時期、佐々木道誉に任せた五条橋の架橋工事が遅々として進まないのを見かね、高経が全て終わらせた。
sen.e: While Takatsune was taking the reins of government, he couldn't bear to watch the slow moving construction of Gojo-bashi Bridge, which was entrusted to Doyo SASAKI, and Takatsune did it himself.
While Takatsune was taking the reins of government, he couldn't bear to watch the slow moving construction of Gojo-bashi Bridge, which was entrusted to Doyo SASAKI, and Takatsune did it himself.
While Takatsune was taking the reins of government, he couldn't bear to watch the slow moving construction of Gojo-bashi Bridge, which was entrusted to Doyo SASAKI, and Takatsune did it himself.

sen.j: 道誉は面目を潰されたと思い、後日将軍邸で行われた高経主催の花見が行われる際、初め出席するとの返事をしたが、当日になってこれを違え、自邸で盛大な花見を催した。
sen.e: When the cherry blossom viewing party, which Takatsune organized, was held at a residence of the shogun, Doyo, who thought he had lost face, had first said he would attend, but he changed on the day and held a big cherry blossom viewing party at his own house.

When the cherry blossom viewing party, which Takatsune organized, was held at a residence of the shogun, Doyo, who thought he had lost face, had first said he would attend, but he changed on the day and held a big cherry blossom viewing party at his own house.

When the cherry blossom viewing party, which Takatsune organized, was held at a residence of the shogun, Doyo, who thought he had lost face, had first said he would attend, but he changed on the day and held a big cherry blossom viewing party at his own house.

sen.j: それは将軍邸での花見が霞むほどで、今度は高経が面目を潰された格好になった。
sen.e: The party was so tremendous that the party at the shogun's residence was over-shadowed, and Takatsune lost face this time.
The party was so tremendous that the party at the shogun's residence was over-shadowed, and Takatsune lost face this time.
The party was so tremendous that the party at the shogun's residence was over-shadowed, and Takatsune lost face this time.

sen.j: 真偽の程はともかく、高経が尊氏、道誉と仲が良くはなかった事を伝える逸話である。
sen.e: Whether or not it is true, these are anecdotes to illustrate that Takatsune was on bad terms with Takauji and Doyo.
Whether or not it is true, these are anecdotes to illustrate that Takatsune was on bad terms with Takauji and Doyo.
Whether or not it is true, these are anecdotes to illustrate that Takatsune was on bad terms with Takauji and Doyo.

sen.j: 官職および位階等の履歴
sen.e: History of his government posts and court ranks
History of his government posts and court ranks
History of his government posts and court ranks

sen.j: ※日付＝旧暦
sen.cmt: 日付は西暦に直して英訳しているので本文は訳出しませんでした。
sen.e: * Date according to old lunar calendar
sen.cmt: 訳しだししました。統一リストに従いました。

sen.j: 1337年（建武 (日本)4・延元2）１月29日、従五位下に叙し、右馬頭に任官。
sen.e: On March 10, 1337, Takatsune was made Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed Uma no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Bureau of Horses).
On March 10, 1337, Takatsune was made Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed Uma no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Bureau of Horses).
On January 29, 1337, Takatsune was made Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed Uma no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Bureau of Horses).
sen.cmt: 日付は、和文に忠実にしました。

sen.j: 1342年（暦応5・興国3）１月15日、従四位下に昇叙し、修理大夫に転任。
sen.e: On February 28, 1342, he was promoted to Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and transferred to Shuri no daibu (Master of the Office of Palace Repairs).
On February 28, 1342, he was promoted to Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and transferred to Shuri no daibu (Master of the Office of Palace Repairs).
On January 15, 1342, he was promoted to Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and transferred to Shuri no daibu (Master of the Office of Palace Repairs).
sen.cmt: 日付は、和文に忠実にしました。

sen.j: 1362年（貞治元・正平 (日本)17）出家し、道朝と号す。
sen.e: In 1362, Takatsune became a priest and identified himself as Docho.
In 1362, Takatsune became a priest and identified himself as Docho.
In 1362, Takatsune became a priest and identified himself as Docho.
